conclusion: Two identical books A and B, each weighing 5N, are divided into several equal parts and alternately stacked on a smooth table.
Book A is fixed in place, and a horizontal force F is applied to the right to pull out book B.
The coefficient of kinetic friction μ is defined as the ratio of the sliding friction force f between the contact surfaces of the paper to the pressure N, i.e., μ = f/N.
The coefficient of kinetic friction μ between any two sheets of paper in the two books is equal.
The table shows the number of trials, number of book divisions, and force F (N) for each trial.
The force required to pull out book B increases as the number of book divisions increases.
The pressure N is equal to the weight of book B, which is 5N.
The sliding friction force f can be calculated using the force F required to pull out book B.
For trial 1, with 2 book divisions, the force F is 4.5N, so f = 4.5N.
For trial 2, with 4 book divisions, the force F is 10.5N, so f = 10.5N.
For trial 3, with 8 book divisions, the force F is 22.5N, so f = 22.5N.
For trial 4, with 16 book divisions, the force F is 46.5N, so f = 46.5N.
The coefficient of kinetic friction μ can be calculated using μ = f/N for each trial.
The coefficient of kinetic friction μ is determined to be 0.4.
